description: A little finagling, but you'll finally see your tv card work. As opposed to 'mythtv' which never works.

The kernel sees my DVB-ATSC tuner, as does several viewing apps, but not this TVHeadend. It thinks I'm using IPTV and won't let me select anything else. Any ideas? Must be a permission issue, but have no idea where to start.
I launch and Terminal starts up, shows a list of commands and such. Actual app does not start. Please advise.
Setup on wizard and closes. Can't login again. Tried no password, some password and tvheadend -c tweaks to no avail

Distributing TVHeadend as a Snap has made distro hopping easier. Thanks!

I found a small omission that fixes Stephen's issue noted on 6 December 2019. My DVB card was not recognized by the Snap version of TVHeadend because the tvheadend:dvb plug had nothing entered as a corresponding slot. Using the documentation at https://snapcraft.io/docs/interface-management, I fixed the problem with this command: 

  snap connect tvheadend:dvb :dvb

Afterward, the command snap connections confirmed that the slot was now set as "dvb" and my tuner now appeared in the TVHeadend web interface.

Tvheadend get 5 stars from me and works fine but install it from here and it is not an official build but one built with Snap and I found it would not let me change things like default recording path - I could not even find the recordings I made and was not prepared to spend the time learning about sanp. I eventually downloaded following these instructions 
https://tvheadend.org/projects/tvheadend/wiki/AptRepositories
summary: Only install this version if you know all about Snap

description:
This snap version of Tvheadend is quick to install and works perfectly.

However unlike the Apt repository version, which will automatically gain access to the entire system (usb freeview devices, hdd etc), by default the snap version does not.
After installing, it is necessary to enable these "connections" in the menu by clicking on the permissions button.

The website snapcraft.io has documentation that explains how to manage the permissions (if using terminal).

I think the importance of these permissions when installing within the Ubuntu Software Center should be made more obvious.
